div1.p: THE PROCEEDINGS ON THE Queen's Commission of the Peace, AND Oyer and Terminer and Goal-Delivery of Newgate, held for the CITY of London, and COUNTY of Middlesex, at Justice-Hall in the OLD-BAILEY.
On Wednesday, and Thursday, being the 14th, and 15th, Days of October, 1702. And in the First Year of her Majesty's Reign.

THE Sessions of Peace, of Oyer and Terminer, and Goal-delivery of Newgate, held at Justice-Hall in the Old-Baily, on Wednesday and Thursday, being the 14th, and 15th, Days of October, 1702, before the Right Honourable Sir
William Gore
, Knt. Lord Mayor of the City of London, and Sir
Salathiel Lovel
, Kt. Recorder of the said City, with divers others of her Majesty's Justices of the Peace, for the City of London, and County of Middlesex.
The Jurors are as followeth.
London Jury.

William Christopher
,

Thomas Wharton
,

James Church
,

Nicholas Eale
,

James Bowton
,

Charles Bywater
,

Abell Ward
,

John Cleere
,

Thomas Harwell
,

Samuel Hall
,

Edward Adams
.
Middlesex Jury.

William Kidgeel
, Gent.

John Johnson
,

Benjamin Noble
,

John East
,

John Tims
,

Robert Rogers
,

Thomas Bootes
,

John Wiburd
,

Robert Taper
.

Richard Bennet
,

Thomas Yeomans
,

Richard Beatnife
.
The Proceedings were as follows.

William Stanton
and
Thomas Bell
, of the Parish of St. Michael Queen-hith
, were Indicted for
feloniously stealing a Sculler-boat, value 50 s. from
George Bignall
, and two Sculls, value 3 s. from
Nicholas Gilbert
, on the 21st of September last. There was no Evidence that saw the Prisoners take the Boat from the place where it was lost, or the Sculls; and the Prisoners alledging their Innocence, saying that they had been drinking at the five Bells in Wood-street with a Friend, and staying late, they came to Queen-hith
and called for a Sculler, but none came; at last they went over some Lighters, where they step'd into the Boat and was taken. The Jury
acquitted them.

Sarah Morrison
, of the Parish of St. Andrews Holborne
, was Indicted for
feloniously stealing 40 Yards of Taffety Ribbon, value 40 s. the Goods of
Rachel Bonner
, on the 7th of October last. The Evidence deposed that the Prisoner came into the Shop, pretending to buy some Ribbon, and took her Gloves, and put them cross her Arms, and leant on the Counter, and took up the Goods, and then went to the Door, and afterwards turned back, and held him in discourse, whilst she got another, and went backwards and forwards three several times, and every time took something, and at last went her ways; but he let her go out of the Shop, and then took her with the Goods upon her; she did not deny the Fact, saying, that she was in Drink and did not know what she did. The Jury found her
Guilty .

Mary Johnson
, of the Parish of St. Giles in the Fields
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing two Worsted Camblet Coats from
James Heming
, on the 13th of October last. The first Evidence deposed, that she saw the Prisoner at the Door. and whilst she went to fetch a Pail of Water, the Prisoner went in and took the Goods; but pursuing her, brought her back again, and the laid them down where some other Goods were. She denied the Fact, saying she knew nothing of it, but could not call any to her Reputation. The Jury found her
Guilty .

Jane Collier
, of the Parish of Hampton
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing 3 Silver Spoons, a Sattin Petticoat with 3 Gold Laces, a Stuff Gown and Petticoat, a Silk Hood and Scarf, and divers other Goods of
Hester Armstrong
, on the 20th of December last. The Prosecutor deposed that the Prisoner was a Servant in the House, and took her opportunity to go away with the Goods; but being afterwards takenand brought before the Justice, she confest the whole Matter. The Jury found her
Guilty .

Elizabeth Price
, of the Parish of St. Dunstans in the West
, was indicted for
breaking the Dwelling-house of
John Lang
, in the Day time, no Person being therein, on the 7th of October last, about two in the Afternoon, and taking thence a Serge Counterpain, and other Goods of the said Lang . The first Evidence deposed that he had an occasion to go to a Gentlemans Chamber in the Temple, and did mistake the Stair-Case, and going up four pair of Stairs he saw a hole broke at three pair of Stairs, and looking saw a Woman peep, but did not see her Face, and mistrusting her to be a Thief, he went down Stairs, and spoke to a Gentleman in the lower Room, desiring him to stop her if she should come down whilst he went to call the Porter, and in the mean time the Prisoner came down one pair of Stairs, where she was taken; upon which they went up Stairs, and looking in the hole found some Chissels; but opening the Door found several Trunks and Boxes broke open, and the Goods pack'd up ready to be carried away. The Prisoner denied the Fact, saying, she come to enquire for her Counsellor, and was told he lived in that Stair-Case; she went up Stairs and was taken when she came down: All which Matters the Jury having considered, found her
Guilty of Felony only, and acquitted her of breaking the House .

Jane Stacy
, of the Parish of St. Buttolphs without Bishopsgate
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing a Kettle, value 3 s. 6 d. from
John Belch
, on the 8th of October last. The Evidence deposed that as he was looking after the Shop two Women came and cheapen'd a Box Iron; but not agreeing on the price, they went away; but the Kettle being missing, he pursued her, and took it upon her in her Apron. The Jury found her
Guilty to the value of 10 d.

Mary Johnson
, of the Parish of St. James Westminster
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing a Trunk, 6 Holland Shirts, 4 pair of Ruffles, 4 Neckcloaths , the Goods of the Honourable
Phillip Howard
, Esq ; on the 16th of September last. But there was no Evidence could prove the Prisoner took it. The Jury
acquitted her.

Anne Spackman
and
Elizabeth Messenger
, of the Parish of St. Giles in the Fields
, were indicted for
feloniously stealing 6 Diaper Napkins from
John Spackman
, on the 7th of September last. There was no Evidence to prove they see them take them; nor nothing being found upon them, and they alledging their Innocenc, the Jury
acquitted them.

Elizabeth Stephens
, of the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields
, was indicted for
breaking the House of
Daniel Saxton
in the Day time, about 7 in the Afternoon, on the 14th of July last, no Person being therein, and taking thence a Stuff Wastcoat and a pair of Breeches of
Rich. Davis
, and a pair of Sheets and Blankets, the Goods of the said Saxton . The Evidence deposed that his Room was robbed and in pursuit he took the Prisoner in the Passage. She denied the Fact, and nothing being found upon her, the Jury
acquitted her.

Cicilla Gregory
, of the Parish of St. Giles in the Fields
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing two Silver Spoons from
Joseph Mathias
, on the 10th of August last. The Prosecutor said that she came into his Chamber, and having a Mess with something in it, with a Siver Spoon, she tasted of it; but being called down to the Door in the mean time, she took two Spoons and went her ways; and said that afterwards he took her by Broomly-street in Mans Cloaths. The Prisoner denied the Fact, and there being nothing found upon her, and she calling divers Persons to her Reputation, the Jury
acquitted her.

Simon Johnson
, of the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields
, was indicted for
Felony, for that he the 11th of June last, at the Fleet, in the Parish of St. Brides, London, did take to Wife one
Susanna Cornwell
, Spinster
, and afterwards, at Knightsbridge, in the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields
, did take to Wife one
S - S -
, Spinster, on the 23d of September following, his former Wife being alive . The first Evidence was the Chaplain of the Fleet, who deposed, that he did marry one Simon Johnson and Susanna Cornwell, and did believe that the Prisoner was the Man; and the Clerk deposed the same. As to the second Marriage, the Prisoner confest the same, saying he would live and die with her; but denied the first Wife, altho' he had owned before that he was married to her; but she having some mistrust that he was going to be married to a second Wife followed him to Knights-bridge in a Coach, where he was married a second time before she came; and the Prisoner looking out of a Window and seeing his first Wife, ran away into Hyde Park, leaving his Hat behind him, never coming near his last Wife after. Another Evidence was the Minister of Knightsbridge, who deposed that the Prisoner and the last Wife came the 23d of September, about eight a Clock in the Morning, with a Licence, upon which he married them. Another Evidence was the Clerk, who deposed that after they were married he earnestly desired him to keep the matter secret. Another Evidence deposed that she heard the Prisoner own when he was in Custody, that he had two Wives, and that the first Wife told her she was with Child by him, and where they were married. Another Evidence deposed, that when he was going to Newgate he did confess that he had two Wives. The Prisoner for himself said, that he was not married to his first Wife. But both Marriages being so plainly proved, the Jury found him
Guilty .

Henry Dodds
, of the Parish of Enfield
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing 2208 Beech Billets, and other Wood , from
Thomas Barnet
, on the 6th of January last. It appeared to be a malicious Prosecution. The Jury
acquitted him, and the Court ordered him a Copy of the Indictment.

Rachel Sampson
, of the Parish of White-chappel
, was indicted for a
Burglary, for breaking the House of
Susan Edwards
in the Night time, on the 28 of September , and taking thence two Cheeses, a pair of Silk Gloves, and a pair of Worsted Stockings, and 7 s. in Money . It appeared that the Prisoner got in and hid her self till they were a Bed, and took the Goods, which she confest when taken. She denied the Fact upon her Trial, saying, she knew nothing of it. The Jury found her
Guilty of Felony only, and acquitted her of the Burglary .

Jane Housden alias Newstead
, of the Parish of St. Andrew's Holborn
, was indicted for High Treason, for
counterfeiting the current Coin of this Kingdom , on the 18th of August last. It appeared that there was an Information given, that the Prisoner followed the Trade of Coining, a Warrant was granted to apprehend her, and going in Holborn, by Turnstile, they met the Prisoner with false Money in her Hand, upon which she dropt upon her Knees, and would have thrust the Money into some Grates of a Window, but was prevented; an other Evidence said, that she had bought several quantities of false Money of the Prisoner, who confest to her, that she had made it. The Prisoner was an Old Offender in this kind, and had nothing to say, only denied the Fact: The Jury found her
Guilty .

Thomas Parry
, of the Parish of St. Andrews Holborn
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing 3 Brass Porridge-pots and a Brass Kettle from
Rich Southey
, on the 17th of July , in the 11th Year of the late King William. The Prisoner alledged he bought them 7 Years ago, and farther said, that he was Prosecuted out of Malice, by reason he had lived so long by the Prosecutor and was never taken up for the same till now. The Jury
acquitted him.

Joseph Day
, of the Parish of St. Clements Danes
, was indicted for
privately stealing 3 pair of Crimson Worsted Stockings, out of the Shop of
Anthony Huslam
, on the 7th of September Last. The Prosecutor said he was fitting in the Shop with his Wife, and on a sudden she saw the Prisoner come from behind the Counter with something under his Arm, and immediately he followed him, and took the Goods upon him. He denied the Fact, saying he did not touch them; but that did not avail him, the Jury found him
Guilty to the value of 4 s. 10 d.

Jane Bourne
was indicted for a Misdemeanor for
uttering false Money, she knowing it so to be . The Evidence deposed that she came into the Shop to buy some French Brandy, and offered a good Guinea to change, which was weighed; but she pretending that she must not give so much for it, and desired her Money again; at last she agreed to have it, and threw down a gilt Shilling instead of the Guinea, and they gave her her change out of it, and she went her way; there was another deposed that she bought a Shift of her, and she gave her a gilt Six-pence instead of a half Guinea; another said, that she came to buy 3 l. of Sugar, and she gave her a gilt Six-pence instead of a half Guinea. She having little to say for herself, the Jury found her
Guilty .

Joseph Bennet
, of the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields
, was indicted for
stealing a Walnut-tree Dressing-box, and 29 Shillings in Money from
David Hutchinson
, on the 22d of September last. There was no Evidence against him, he was
acquitted .

Thomas Twist
,
Jane Williams
and
Mary Buck
, of the Parish of Chelsea
, were indicted for
breaking the House of
William Stubbington
, in the day time, on the 18th of July last, and taking a Copper, a pair of stuff Curtains, and divers other Goods . It appeared that the Door was broke open whilst the Prosecutor was gone out early to Market, and the Goods gone. There was other Evidence who saw the Women near the House, and saw one of them carry the Copper upon her Head, and the other the Bundles, and the Man was not with them; which the Jury considering,
acquitted the Man, and found the two Women
Guilty of Felony only .

Lancelot Roberts
, of the Parish of Stepney
, was indicted for
robbing his Lodgings, granted to him by Contract, on the 10th of January last. and taking 20 l. weight of Feathers, a blanket, Sheet and divers other Goods of
Mark Hooks
deceased. There was no Evidence against him, he was
acquitted .

Sarah Stephens alias Manshty
, of the Parish of Stepny
, was indicted for
picking the pocket of
David Hughes
, on the 13th of October last, and taking from him a Linnen-purse work'd with Cruel, and 20 s in Money, numbred . The Prosecutor said that he was drinking at a House where the Prisoner was, and going his way over Goodmans-fields
, she overtook him again, and would have him to make her drink, which he refused, and on a suddain got her Hand into his Pocket, which he fealing, she snatched it out again with the Purse, and ran away; there was other Evidences who said, that she confest, where she had left the Purse, and accordingly found it by her Directions. She denied the Fact, saying, she found it in the Street, but could not prove it, or call any to her Reputation, the Jury found her
Guilty .

Martha Lewin
of the Parish of St. Giles without Cripplegate
, was indicted for
feloniously stealing an Indian Sattin Gown, and divers other Goods of
Martha Roberts
, and a silk Hood the Goods of
John Mercer
, on the 14th of September last. The Prosecutor deposed that the Prisoner was a Servant , and took the Goods, which she confest when taken and brought before the Justice.She had nothing to say for her self, the Jury found her
Guilty .

Elizabeth Smith
was indicted for a Misdemeanour for
breakings the House of
John Walters
, in the day time, with intention to steal his Goods while a little Girl went out to fetch a pint of Drink, in the mean time the Prisoner came and opened the Door; but the Girl returning, she was for getting away, but the Girl laid hold of her, and cried out, and People coming, they took her, and found a pick-lock key in her Bosom, which lock'd and unlock'd the Door very well. It was fully proved, the Jury found her
Guilty .

Mary Cook
, of the Parish of Stepny
, was indicted
for feloniously stealing a stuff Gown and 2 stuff Petticoats, and other Goods of
Isabella Holms
, Widow , on the 14th of October last. The Evidence deposed that he saw the Prisoner come out of the House with a lap full of Things, but he pursuing her she drop'd them. She had little to say for her self. The Jury found her
Guilty .

Tobias Maccarty, alis Dathy Maccarty, alias Jeremy Maccarty
, of the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields
, was indicted for
marrying a second Wife
, the first
being alive . There was no Evidence against him, the Jury
acquitted him.

Mary Niccolls alias Alderson
, was indicted for
Forgery for Forging several Deeds of Assignments ; which Matter the Court not thinking fit to try before the Title could be prov'd at Common Law, the Jury were ordered to inquire of it no further.
Received Sentence of Death 2.
Jane Housden to be burnt, and Sarah Stephens to be hang'd.
Burnt in the Hand Simon Johnson.
Burnt in the Left-Cheek 10.
Mary Buck, Jane Collier, Mary Cook, Joseph Day, Mary Johnson, Martha Lewin, Sarrah Morrison, Elizabeth Price, Rachel Sampson and Jane Williams.
To be whipt Jane Stacy.
Jane Housden and Sarah Stephens pleaded their Bellies, and a Jury of Matrons being Impanelled, who found them with quick Child.
Jane Bourne fin'd 20 Nobles, and to stand 3 times on the Pillory, without Temple-bar, at the May-pole in the Strand and Charing cross.
Elizabeth Smith fin'd 5 l. and to be whipt at the usual place and times.

*** The History of Living Men, or Characters of the Royal Family, the Ministers of State, and the principal Natives of the three Kingdoms; being an Essay on a Thousand Persons that are now living, with a Poem upon each Life: Dedicated to his Royal Highness Prince George of Denmark, Price 1 s.
*** Petticoat-Government; In a Letter to the Court-Ladies, by the Author of the Post-Angel. Price 1 s.
The New Quevedo, Or, a Vision of Charon's Passengers: From the Creation of the World, down to this present Year 1702. With their Names, Qualities, and particular Crimes. Price 1 s.
The second Part of the New Quevedo, or a further Vision of Charon's Passengers; with their Names, Qualities, and particular Crimes. Price 1 s.

Eight Fables on the present Posture of Affairs in Europe, viz. The Devil and the Priest, or Porto Carero's Will: The Courtier: The Pilgrims: The Usurers and Merchants: The Ingrates: The Partizan: The Confederacy: The Interview: To which is prefix'd, Aesop's Advice, both to the Princes and People of Europe. Price 6 d.

||+||. A Vindication of Magna Charta, as the Summary of English Rights and Liberties; in which its Antiquity, and the Confirmations procured to it in several Reigns, are fully set forth. The glorious Actions of the Peers of England, in order to maintain the Privileges of the People, are related and defended: And the excellency of the old English Constitution, as the noblest Constitution in the World. Price 12 d.

*** An Argument proving, that the Imposition of the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper, as a Qualification for a secular Office, is (1.) Contrary to the express Laws of God. (2.) Contrary to the Doctrines of the Church of England. (3.) Contrary to the Doctrines of the Dissenters. And (4.) Contrary-to the National and Natural Rights of all Mankind. In which, the Reasonableness and Necessity of taking away the Sacramental Test at this Juncture, is particularly consider'd. Price 6 d.
*** The present Condition of the English Navy, set forth in a Dialogue betwixt young Fudge of the Admiralty, and Captain Steerwel an Oliverian Commander. Price 6 d.

Plantation Justice, shewing the Constitution of their Courts, and what sort of Judges they have in them: By which Merchants may see the occasions of their great Losses and Sufferings in the Plantation Trade: Lawyers may see such a Model of Justice as they could not have thought of; and Others may see how those Parts of the World are governed. The second Edition. Price 3 d.
All Sold by Elizabeth Miller,

Robert Whitledge, Book-binder, at the Bible in Creedane, within Ludgate, sells all sorts of Bibles and Common-Prayers, Tate and Brady's Singing-Psalms, and other Books, neatly Bound, at reasonable rates.
ADVERTISEMENTS.

B. Lilburn, that formerly Lived on Ludgate-hill, next to the Kings Arms Tavern near Fleet-Bridge, now Lives at the Golden-Board, and Ball in the Great Old-Baily, near Ludgate hill. Who maketh and felleth, (and has done this 20 Years) the Water for taking away the Freckels, Pimple, Worms, Morphew, and red Marks of the Small-pox in the Face: With Elixir Salutis, Balsamum Vitoe, Tinctura Vitoe. Waters and Ointments for the Eyes, Powders, Dentrifices, Elixirs, Essences, Oils, Spirits, &c. both for Ornament, and Curing all Diseases incident to Humane Bodies; but more especially relating to the Female Sex, likewise Judgment upon Urine.
The Anti-scorbutick Pills, price 1 s. 6 d the Box.
The Elixir for the Collick, and Gripes. I s. the Bottle.
The Ointment for sore Nipples, and the Piles, I s. the Pot.
An Ointment for Redness, Pustules, Heat, Scabs, Ring-worms, Titters, Itch or breaking out in the Face, or else where, price 1 s. the Pot.
The Ointment for Aches, and Strains, 6 d. the Pot.

The Water for the Freckles, Pimples, &c. The Author has for some Years past, left with several for Sale; who now doth understand, they have been abused by Counterfeits; which to prevent for the future, doth desire those that have bought from them - and not found the Effect-answer the Ends for which it is proposed, to acquaint her with it, and where they bought it - and likewise to take nor tice of the Seal, viz. The 3 Water-budgets, and B. L. on the top of the Seal.
The Price of the half Pint-bottle 3 s.
